body: Can u pls try just one provider and see? Namely, use cpu execution provider as baseline, and test cuda execution provider to compare with.

@rayray41414141, Could it be related to other application or service is running?

In ubuntu VM with T4 GPU, I saw the CPU is busy (You might need change the test script to use I/O binding to avoid copy inputs/outputs between CPU & GPU).

10000 runs is like the following:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30328909/194971202-28abdbcd-b19a-40ff-b0c5-42b65a7718ff.png)
I did saw small jump (from 160 to 210) in a short period of time. Probably not a big issue since 99.9% percentile is 170.7, which is only slightly larger than average.

Test script:
```
import time
import numpy as np
import onnxruntime as rt
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

times = []
input_shape = (1,512,7808,6)

print(rt.get_available_providers()[1:])

sess = rt.InferenceSession(
    "model.onnx", providers=rt.get_available_providers()[1:])

input_name = sess.get_inputs()[0].name

warm_up = 3
for i in range(warm_up):
    x = np.random.random(input_shape)
    x = x.astype(np.float32)
    sess.run(None, {input_name: x})[0]

for i in range(10000):
    x = np.random.random(input_shape)
    x = x.astype(np.float32)
    input_ready = time.perf_counter_ns()
    sess.run(None, {input_name: x})[0]  # TODO: Use IO/Binding to avoid data copy between CPU & GPU
    times.append(((time.perf_counter_ns() - input_ready)/1000000))

for p in [50, 75, 95, 99, 99.9]:
    print(p, np.percentile(times, p))

print(times)

y = np.array(times)
x = np.arange(10000)
plt.scatter(x, y)
plt.show()
```

> Can u pls try just one provider and see? Namely, use cpu execution provider as baseline, and test cuda execution provider to compare with.

Alright, with only CUDAExecutionProvider selected it still has these outliers. 
I've alterd this line:
```
sess = rt.InferenceSession(
    ".\\model.onnx", providers=[rt.get_available_providers()[1]])
```

Result is this:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195016484-5a467f68-61d3-4588-92b2-43a97eb3bcf8.png)

Regarding the CPU, that one is still running.

I have implemented IO/Bindings like this:
```
times = []
times_full = []
input_shape = (1,512,7808,6)

sess = rt.InferenceSession(
    ".\\model.onnx", providers=[rt.get_available_providers()[1]]) #exclude TensorrtExecutionProvider
input_name = sess.get_inputs()[0].name
output_name = sess.get_outputs()[0].name

for ii in tqdm(range(3000)):
    x = np.random.random(input_shape)
    x = x.astype(np.float32)

    bind_timer = time.perf_counter_ns()

    io_binding = sess.io_binding()
    io_binding.bind_cpu_input(input_name, x)
    io_binding.bind_output(output_name)

    input_ready = time.perf_counter_ns()
    
    sess.run_with_iobinding(io_binding)
    times.append(((time.perf_counter_ns() - input_ready)/1000000))
    y = io_binding.copy_outputs_to_cpu()[0]
    times_full.append(((time.perf_counter_ns() - bind_timer)/1000000))
```

But there are still some spikes. Interestingly, the measured time is down to half of the time measured with normal input/outputs. So uploading and downloading takes the same time as infering it. 

The PC is not doing anything, except running this python code and RemoteDesktop.

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195017575-0a4c509e-cf5c-40a9-9dac-8ecb37003cfa.png)

NEXT, I will try your test script. Just in case.

> Can u pls try just one provider and see? Namely, use cpu execution provider as baseline, and test cuda execution provider to compare with.

So the baseline would be this than? 
CPU as execution provider
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195087416-1f5822c1-4be6-479d-b6a1-bea2702bb12e.png)

Generated with this code:
```
times = []
input_shape = (1,512,7808,6)

sess = rt.InferenceSession(
    ".\\model.onnx", providers=[rt.get_available_providers()[2]]) #exclude TensorrtExecutionProvider
input_name = sess.get_inputs()[0].name

for ii in tqdm(range(3000)):
    x = np.random.random(input_shape)
    x = x.astype(np.float32)
    input_ready = time.perf_counter_ns()
    
    sess.run(None, {input_name: x})[0]
    times.append(((time.perf_counter_ns() - input_ready)/1000000))
```
There are still some spikes and this weird part where the time drops temporarily below 4000ms .. 
As I already mentioned the PC is totally idle, except the python code and RemoteDesktop.
Do you @ytaous  have any idea what I could change?

@tianleiwu So no I have tested yours too.

this is without IO/Bindings 
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195117486-aaa7546e-9c5a-4ad7-8ca1-cc6dd6b61a86.png)

and this with IO/Bindings

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195117571-cd3b898e-2c87-4600-b6ca-378d09f7b444.png)

Do you have any idea what else I could have wrong?

@tianleiwu @ytaous 

Is it possible that this is network related? Like could it be that this type of network is not memory efficient and sometimes the GPU has to free memory? Even if I use IO/Bindings and do always have the same size of input..?

As far as I know perf_counter_ns is the most accurate timer, otherwise this could be a problem too? 

Could I test a onnx file, which has constant inference times for any of you guys?

@rayray41414141, there are a few things to try:
(1) Use nvidia-smi to monitor which process is using GPU during one test run.
(2) Modify script to keep inputs and output in GPU memory, and see whether the spike disappear. If so, it is likely large memory copy has paging.
(3) Look for signs of thread switch like this: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-2000-server/cc938606(v=technet.10)?redirectedfrom=MSDN
(4) use `nvprof --cpu-thread-tracing on --cpu-profiling-thread-mode separated` to profile, see https://docs.nvidia.com/hpc-sdk/pgi-compilers/18.10/x86/profiler-users-guide/index.htm#nvprof-command-line-options-cpu for more options.

> @rayray41414141, there are a few things to try: (1) Use nvidia-smi to monitor which process is using GPU during one test run. (2) Modify script to keep inputs and output in GPU memory, and see whether the spike disappear. If so, it is likely large memory copy has paging. (3) Look for signs of thread switch like this: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-2000-server/cc938606(v=technet.10)?redirectedfrom=MSDN (4) use `nvprof --cpu-thread-tracing on --cpu-profiling-thread-mode separated` to profile, see https://docs.nvidia.com/hpc-sdk/pgi-compilers/18.10/x86/profiler-users-guide/index.htm#nvprof-command-line-options-cpu for more options.

Oke so

1.) I was running multiple tests and there was never another process using the GPU except the python process.

2.) I have modified the script as follows, but the spikes remained:
```
    x = np.random.random(input_shape)
    x = x.astype(np.float32)
        
    X_ortvalue = rt.OrtValue.ortvalue_from_numpy(x, 'cuda', 0)
    Y_ortvalue = rt.OrtValue.ortvalue_from_shape_and_type([1, 512, 7808, 5], np.float32, 'cuda', 0)  # Change the shape to the actual shape of the output being bound

    io_binding = sess.io_binding()
    io_binding.bind_input(name=input_name, device_type=X_ortvalue.device_name(), device_id=0, element_type=np.float32, shape=X_ortvalue.shape(), buffer_ptr=X_ortvalue.data_ptr())
    io_binding.bind_output(name=output_name, device_type=Y_ortvalue.device_name(), device_id=0, element_type=np.float32, shape=Y_ortvalue.shape(), buffer_ptr=Y_ortvalue.data_ptr())
    
    sess.run_with_iobinding(io_binding)
```

3.) I did this and for me it does not look like there is a specific increase of context switches. I mean, if the overal activity increases should the amount of switches also increase? Anyway, here is one of the results:
For this test:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195340255-542333de-8b9b-4a08-80d7-d0156ee4301c.png)

I've generated this PerfMon output:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195340569-dee1d11d-adda-4046-a192-a25de4fad184.png)
The yellow line marks the test period and the black dots mark the first 4 major outliers from the first chart.
What does seem interesting to me, is that there is a symmertic-like pattern of the context switches (blue/green line). But these are happening during idle times too. 

4.)  If I execute this line of code, I get the `ncprof.exe stopped working`-pop up ðŸ˜… At the moment, I've no idea why, BUT!
But I ran it without any parameters and the times where stable!
Command:
`nvprof --log-file "profiling.log" --csv python .\script_IO_onGPU.py`

The result was:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195343282-b0102d46-b5bb-42cc-9f6c-1423b0db08e0.png)

the question now is, WHY?

EDIT_2:
Further into the problem it seems that the spikes are not allways happening.

@rayray41414141, please output the nvprof result to a file with a parameter (`-o output.nvvp`), then share the output file. You can import the file to Visual Profiler (nvvp). From the timeline, you shall be able to identify those places that having a spike of time. Then take a look at GPU/CPU activity at those spots.

@tianleiwu 
Yea, it took a while to genenerate the ouput. It seems like these spikes are not that frequent using nvprof.

Apparently, the spikes come from the cudaStreamSynchronize Runtime API call. 

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90267929/195638706-cf46377e-84fd-41fe-8348-da5a8d3183d1.png)

You can download the full output.nvvp [HERE](https://github.com/rayray41414141/nvvp_output). 

The biggest spike is at 266.4 seconds uptime.
There are a couple more at:
* 12.75s
* 13.85s

@rayray41414141,  it is weird that cudaStreamSyncronze does not return when kernels on the stream has finished. There are two possible causes: (1) host thread is not active at that time. (2) some bug in device driver or WDDM.  
For 1, need cpu thread tracing as I mentioned earlier. 
For 2, you can try upgrade CUDA (including driver) and cuDNN to latest version, and try our 1.13 RC: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/13285

At the meantime, we will try to reproduce it in some Windows machines.

@tianleiwu 
Took me longer than expected, but this does not seem to be possible .. ðŸ˜¬

But I managed to install latest versions and the 1.13 RC.. Will keep you up to date.
And thank you very much for your help till now!

I have to test it further, but it seems like the spikes do only occure if I actively use the PC.
Is there an other way to trace CPU activity, other than with cpu_tracing parameter?
